description.div: Introduction to the forms and functions of theatre and dramatic literature in the historical development of Western cultural traditions. While the theatre always reflects the aesthetic and philosophical concerns of the cultural era, the objective of the course is to determine the unique aesthetics of the theatre as an art form by exploring such issues as the relationship between the literary text and the text in performance; the changing role of theatre in culture historically; the various theatre research methods (historical, critical, experimental).

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation.

description.div: For course description, see THEA 112G.
Introduction to the essentials of the actor's craft: concentration, relaxation, sensory awareness, improvisation, and basic script analysis.
Continuation of THEA 114, with greater emphasis on the development of emotional control as it applies to scene work.

course.title: Principles of Design for Theatre and Film

description.div: Introduction of the basic elements of design and the development of visual and perceptual skills. Develop an extensive portfolio of 2D and 3D visual projects through experimentation with various media.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation.

notes.div: University Honors Seminar 189H is required of all students in the University Honors Program.

description.div: Topic varies.

Basic theoretical and practical application of the technical theatre production, including scenery design, construction, use and requirements and related areas that are considered scenic or influence scenery, its design and construction. Related areas include types of stages, facilities, equipment and tool use and maintenance, materials, drafting fundamentals, painting, moving scenery, properties and safety.

Fundamental concepts of play direction, play selection, script analysis and interpretation, artistic choices, articulating of ideas, communication with actors, and critique. Rehearsal and presentation of realistic scenes.
Introduction to the methods and techniques of makeup.

notes.div: Course is a prerequisite for THEA 411.

description.div: Introduction and appreciation of the basic theory and practice of stage lighting. Exploration and application of elements of design (color, texture, intensity, line, composition) as they relate to lighting for live performance. Learning the basic tools of the lighting from the actual lighting instruments to the creating and timing of lighting cues.
Intensive concentration, emotional and sensory work focused on the problems of characterization. Emphasis on close script analysis and scene work.
Continuation of THEA 223. Development of a sensitive emotional instrument as it affects characterization. Scene study and appropriate exercises in concentration and sensory development.

Survey of dramatic literature and texts in performance designed to provide a broad understanding of the forms and functions of drama, historically, across diverse cultural traditions. Methods for analyzing thematic issues, as those related to gender, race, and ethnicity, as they appear in 12-15 plays.

Training in the use of voice for the stage, including anatomy of the voice-producing mechanism, the actor's improvement of voice, breath control for the theatre, resonance and flexibility of tone for characterization, and vocal response to a wide range of emotional stimuli in dramatic literature.
Application of phonetics to stage diction and dialects. Mastery for characterization on stage of the distinguishing characteristics of foreign dialects, regional variants, and stage diction.
Movement training focusing on the process of building a physical characterization, physical conditioning and flexibility, kinesthetic awareness, and movement improvisation.
Application of the techniques developed in THEA 255 to the plays of Shakespeare, Moliere, and selected Commedia dell'Arte.
A practical introduction to the aesthetics, equipment, and production workflow for digital video production.

notes.div: Use of the University Theatre Laboratory.

description.div: Intensive application of principles of interpretative and technical theatre practice.

notes.div: Use of the University Theatre Laboratory.

description.div: Intensive application of principles of interpretative and technical theatre practice.
Survey of management techniques for the theatre including theoretical and practical application.
Theatre management: strategic planning; marketing; audience development; grant writing; and company and front-of-the-house management.

Exploration of periods and styles of play direction from Classical Greek to contemporary American Realism and theatre for young audiences. Rehearsal and production of student directed scenes and short plays in Laboratory Theatre.
Beginning writing for the theatre; starting with the composition of short dramatic scenes and working toward the completion of a one-act play.
Theatre from Ancient Greece through Elizabethan period.
Theatre from French Neoclassicism to the present.
Survey and practical application of the major aspects of making and leading improvisation with young people.
Fundamental concepts of dramaturgy. Theoretical and practical applications.
Web design, usability and interactive media.

prerequisite.div: Students must be enrolled in the Nebraska at Oxford study abroad program.

notes.div: Lecturers and tutors for the two courses are from Oxford University faculty and staff. Field trips and cultural excursions will supplement the course lectures and tutorials.

description.div: Shakespeare and the well-known literature of England since the Middle Ages.
Creation, animation, lighting and rendering moving images.

notes.div: AHIS/MUSC/THEA 388 will not count towards the major or minor in studio art and/or art history.

description.div: Interdisciplinary approach to the enjoyment and understanding of the contemporary (first half of the twentieth century) arts.

notes.div: AHIS/MUNM/THEA 389 will not count toward the major or minor in studio art and/or art history.

description.div: Interdisciplinary approach to the enjoyment and understanding of the contemporary (1945 to the present) arts.

prerequisite.div: Open to juniors who are candidates for degrees with distinction, with high distinction, and with highest distinction in the Hixson-Lied College of Fine and Performing Arts.

description.div: Actor's methods of character development in the major styles of acting including Realistic Drama, Elizabethan, Comedy, Theatre of the Absurd, Musical Theatre, and others, and the acting profession itself. Specific content for each semester may be obtained from the teaching faculty.

Actor movement training intended for the graduate and advanced undergraduate. Focus on the process of building a physical characterization, tumbling, kinesthetic awareness, movement improvisation, period styles, court dancing, mask, Commedia dell'Arte, and stage combat.

prerequisite.div: THEA 253, THEA 254, or equivalent and permission.

description.div: Introduces actors to techniques ranging from commercial voice-over techniques, dialect mastery, and singing, to specialized voice/speech techniques for stage, screen, and new media.
The creation of various costume accessories, ornaments and hand properties categorized by the profession as costume crafts.
Auditioning process, including resumes, interviews, preparation of pieces (forms, styles, and genres), cold readings, songs, etc.

course.title: Advanced Projects in Acting and/or Directing

prerequisite.div: (Acting) THEA 112G or 115, 114, 204, 401/801 or equivalent and permission; (Directing) THEA 303, 401/801, 403/803, 410/810, 412/812, 418/818, and permission.

description.div: Selected performance in acting and directing in University Theatre, and Experimental Theatre.
Projects in scene design, costume design, lighting design, sound design, or technical direction. Planning and execution of designs for actual production.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs theatre arts, including THEA 201 and 202.

description.div: Theory and practice of stage lighting. Instruments and control systems employed in lighting the stage. Color in light, its effect upon costume, makeup, and settings. Planning of light plots.
Intensive work in designing lighting for theatre, dance, musicals, and opera.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs theatre arts including THEA 201 and 202.

description.div: Theory and practice of scene design. Application of the principles of design to stage settings. Development of the scene design for a play through sketches, color plates, models, and drawings.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs theatre arts, including THEA 201 and 202, and 412/812.

description.div: Theory and practice of scene design. Rendering techniques, period research, and multi-set productions.
Advanced lighting design through the rendering of light story boards.

course.title: Production Design for Film and Television

description.div: Theory and practice of production design for the camera. Research, design techniques, tools, and aspects specific to film and television.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs theatre arts, including THEA 201, and permission.

description.div: Computer Aided Design (CAD) as it applies to scenic, costume, and lighting design. Emphasis on two-dimensional drafting, three-dimensional modeling, and computer graphics.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs theatre arts, including THEA 201 and 202.

description.div: Theory and practice of stage costume designs. Principles of design as they apply to theatrical costuming. Development of costume designs for the characters in a play through sketches, drawings, and color plates.
In-depth costume design in the areas of design conception and techniques of design communication. Application of principles learned in Costume Design I.

In-depth theoretical and practical application of organization, materials, and techniques necessary for the planning, execution, maintenance, and use of stage scenery, and the proper and safe use and maintenance of the stage and shop facilities.
Advanced techniques and practice in technical drafting as applied to theatrical scenic construction.
Practice in planning of a theatre facility, including program writing, working with consultants and architects, equipment specification, space allocation, codes and regulations.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs theatre arts, including THEA 201 or permission.

description.div: Techniques and practice of rendering for scene and costume design.

course.title: Directing and/or Dramaturgy and/or Stage Management Seminar I

description.div: Modern dramatic literature, directing dramaturgy, and stage management theory and practice. Stanislavski to Peter Brook.

course.title: Directing and/or Dramaturgy and/or Stage Management Seminar II

description.div: Modern dramatic literature, directing dramaturgy, and stage management theory and practice. New voices.
Advanced application of film lighting concepts and techniques.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs theatre arts, including THEA 112G, 335, and 336 or equivalent.

description.div: History and development of the professional American theatre from the beginning to 1900. Includes selected American plays which best characterize the period under consideration.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs theatre arts, including THEA 112G, 335, and 336 or equivalent.

description.div: History and development of the professional American theatre from 1900 to the present day. Includes selected American plays which best characterize the period.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs theatre arts, including THEA 112G or 115, 331 or equivalent, and permission.

description.div: Practice leading to the composition of a three-act play or equivalent long play.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs theatre arts including THEA 201, or permission.

description.div: Techniques and practice of scene painting for theatre, film, and television. Texture simulation, faux finishes, and realistic drop painting.
Life as a professional theatre design. Contracts, taxes, record keeping, resumes, portfolios, interviewing, job hunting and legal considerations.
Develop the skills required to successfully direct a film. Critically analyze a script; shape an actor's performance and balance the technical demands of each scene.
Most frequently produced plays 1652-1989 on European stages (excluding England). Structural aspects and reasons for the play's popularity among performers and audiences.
Theory and practice of sound design for live theatre. Extensive work with recording, mixing, effects, and playback devices.

Advanced work with recording, editing, and playback devices. Training in digital editing using the ProTools LE platform. Planning and execution of full-length, realized, sound designs for departmental mainstage productions.
Advanced application of studio and field recording techniques and Digital Audio Workstation (DAW) editing.

Advanced training in the integration of acting, movement, and singing skills for the performance of musical theatre. Training in artistic decision making that generates a character within a musical. Focus on a discipline of preparation and the resulting practice of performance; practical experiences with solos, duets, and ensembles from American Musical Theatre Repertoire.
Theory and practice of rigging for live theatre. Extensive work with fly systems, rope systems, and standard rigging hardware.
Advanced study of theatre arts and crafts.
Advanced compositing and 3D simulations.
Modeling, texturing, rigging, animating, lighting and rendering 3D objects.

course.title: Capstone Project in Film or New Media

description.div: Supervised planning and production of thesis projects in film or new media.
History of technological innovation in film. Sound, film format, color systems, lenses and lighting that have enhanced the finished product in the film industry.

prerequisite.div: BRDC 370 or ENGL 252 or 254 or 259A or THEA 331 or permission.

description.div: Character development, story structure, and problem solving. Writing for the short film.

prerequisite.div: BRDC 269; THEA 114, 201 and 202; BRDC 474/874 or ENGL 252 or 254 or 259A or THEA 331 or permission.

notes.div: Students must have access to a camcorder.

description.div: "Film grammar" and non-sync film production.

course.title: Seminar in Film Production and/or New Media

description.div: Analysis of advanced projects in screenwriting, film production, digital animation, and new media.

course.title: Advanced Projects in Film Production and/or New Media

description.div: Projects in screenwriting, film production, digital animation, and new media.

course.title: Post Production for Film and New Media

description.div: Advanced studio software and techniques.
The budgeting, organizational, managerial and supervisory skills required by a creative film producer - from financing to distribution.
Creating moving text and images using compositing and animation software. Also an introduction to basic 3D animation.
Development and integration of graphics, video and other digital media to assemble a portfolio of creative work.

notes.div: All projects are produced in film or digital video.

description.div: Advanced film production techniques including sync-sound, lighting, lab post-production and film business. Small group production of Cenema Verite's Experimental and Narrative short films.

course.title: Advanced Projects in Directing, Theatre Management and/or Stage Management

description.div: Selected projects in directing, theatre management, and/or stage management in University Theatre or Theatrix.
Structured internships with professional organizations or individuals outside the University of Nebraska-Lincoln campus or with Nebraska Educational Telecommunications.

course.title: Capstone Project in Film or New Media

description.div: Supervised planning and production of thesis projects in film or new media.

prerequisite.div: Open to seniors who are candidates for degrees with distinction, with high distinction, and with highest distinction in the Hixson-Lied College of Fine and Performing Arts; good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation.

description.div: Specific content for each semester may be obtained from the teaching faculty. The actor’s methods of character development in the major styles of acting including Realistic Drama, Elizabethan, Comedy, Theatre of the Absurd, Musical Theatre, and others, and the acting profession itself.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs theatre arts and dramatic literature

description.div: Dramatic theory from Aristotle to Lessing with emphasis on the relationship of theory and practice on the stage.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs theatre arts and dramatic literature

description.div: Dramatic theory continued from Lessing to the present.

prerequisite.div: 12 hrs theatre arts including THEA 201 and 202

description.div: Theory and practice of scene design. Application of the principles of design to stage settings. Development of the scene design for a play through sketches, color plates, models, and drawings.
Advanced practices in scenic rendering for theatre and film.
Advanced application of film lighting concepts and techniques.
Practice in using various media and plate design; rendering techniques and costume plate experimentation to achieve variety in the portfolio, reflecting the mood and texture of each theatrical work.
Advanced costume design techniques in specific types of performance arts.
Significant questions in dramatic theory and practice of theatre and film production, beginning with Aristotle and continuing to film theory.
Systematic approach for analyzing a play based on the four works of Stanislavski.
Projects, planning, and execution of various forms and styles involving the communication process between director and designer.
Practical work on scenes with actors and directors from selected realistic plays.
Further practical work on scenes with actors and directors, involving classical plays, verse drama, expressionistic pieces, or musical comedy.
Introduces the graduate student to contemporary university level teaching theories and their classroom applications.

prerequisite.div: Admission to masters degree program and permission of major adviser

description.div: Prereq or parallel: THEA 810, 812, 818 and 932. Problems and theories of scenery, costume, and lighting design for ballet, opera, musicals, and legitimate plays. Discussion of student projects and designed full-scale productions.

prerequisite.div: Undergraduate major in theatre arts including 9 hrs theatre history and evolution of dramatic theory

description.div: Specialized topics in theatre history.
Practical projects related to a professional theatre organization.

prerequisite.div: Admission to doctoral degree program and permission of supervisory committee chair
